title: How to write a letter to a parent asking their children for school fee - Quora

response.answer_text: Are you the director of the school? Or have you been assigned this job? The director should know the answer to this question. This is what I would do. First, determine who is going to sign the letter. Then you must either write AS that person OR introduce yourself and explain that you are writing FOR that person. You do not need to explain why. Second, I would come right out and say, “I am asking that you send or bring in [the amount in your currency] for [the child’s name] tuition for [state the period of time it covers] by [a date].” Third, I would describe what the fee is spent on (salaries, utilities, loans for equipment and the building, etc.). “This money is used to covers these costs and we cannot provide an education without them.” If you offer financial arrangements (such as monthly payments) I would mention it here. Also include who to set those up with and how that person can be reached. Usually fees are paid when a child is enrolled. This leads me to believe these fees are late. If so, you need to say something about this and what will happen if the fees aren’t paid by a certain date. Basically, this is a business letter. They are much more cut and dry than a personal letter. You state the purpose and get to the point. You provide information. You state consequences. You are civil but don’t dance around the purpose of your letter. At least in the US that is how they are done. If in your country it is standard to include a lot of politenesses then do that. Good luck!

Emerson Elementary School Sports Event Bill Smith-Grade 6 To: Parents of Bill Smith Dear Parent/s, I am excited to announce the sports event of a lifetime. Our school has been flagged as the school to host this years National Sporting Events. The cost per student to attend is $45.00. Each student needs to have this fee in by the end of this month so we can add them to our sports events roster. I hope we can count on your support and see you there. Sincerely, Charles Collins Emerson Elementary Teacher Simply replace items and names as necessary,
